Halawy*, Mohamed A. Mohamed, Suzan F. Abd El-Hafez Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Qena 83511, Egypt Received 6 December 1993; accepted 27 June 1994 Abstract Catalytic dehydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol was studied over C0304-Ni0/MgO catalysts containing 20 wt% of Co304 and NiO, or mixture of both oxides with different molar ratios. Catalysts were prepared from the corresponding nitrates (i.e. Co(N03)2-6H20 and Ni(N03)2-6H20) and supported on MgO. Catalyst precursors were examined by TG, DTG and DTA, and were calcined between 500-700 C for 5 h in air. The surface area of these samples were calculated using the BET method. Those catalysts calcined at 500 C were characterized by XRD analysis. The amount of excess surface oxygen for these catalysts was calculated iodometrically. Basicity measurements were estimated by the adsorption of acidic molecules using pulse technique method. The vapour-phase dehydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol (IP), has been carried out over the catalysts calcined between 500700 C. All catalysts showed 99.5% selectivity towards acetone formation. A correlation between the catalytic activity and the basicity of these catalysts has been made. The activation energy and the order of the dehydrogenation reaction of IP over some catalysts are given. Keywords: Cobalt; Dehydrogenation; Isopropyl alcohol; Magnesium; Nickel; Supported catalysts; Transition metal oxides 1. Introduction A variety of active catalysts are widely used today in most industrial operations, such as oxides of transition elements e.g., Co304 [ 1 ] , Ni0 [ 2] as well as the supported catalysts of these oxides (for example, Coo/A1203 [3], Co304/Si02 [4], Ni-supported catalysts [5,6], Co0/MgO and Ni0/Mg0 [7,8] ). MgO is probably one of the most important among the alkaline earth oxides as stabilizer or support. This may be due to its very high melting point ca. 2852 C *Corresponding author. 0304-5102/94/$07.00 1994 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved SSD10304-5102(94)00125-1 192 S.A. Halawy et al. /Journal ofMolecular Catalysis 94 (1994) 191-201 [9] . Several articles have been published on the characterization of Ni0-MgO and Coo-MgO systems using electron spin resonance spectroscopy [ 10], XRD and UV-Visible reflectance spectroscopy [ 11 ] and photoelectron spectroscopy [ 12]. Also, many studies have dealt with the surface and catalytic properties of metal ions/MgO compounds [ 13,14]. The aim of the present investigation is to study the effect of catalyst composition of Co-Ni/Mg oxide system, prepared at different temperatures, towards the dehydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol. 2. Experimental 2.1. Materials and techniques MgO was obtained by calcination of MgC03 (Prolabo, France) at 900 C, for 4 h, in air. Samples containing 20 wt% of Co304 or NiO, or a mixture of both oxides containing different molar ratios, supported on 80 wt% (g/g) MgO, were prepared as follows: Calculated amounts of both Co (N03)2 - 6Hz0 and Ni(N03)2 - 6H20 (BDH England), as shown in Table 1, were dissolved in 50 ml doubly distilled water, then (20 g) MgO was suspended in the nitrate solution. The mixtures were then evaporated till dryness over a water bath, with continuous stirring. The resulting materials were dried at 120 C, in an oven, overnight. The mixtures were calcined, in air, for 5 h in the temperature range 500-700 C. Thermogravimetry (TG), derivative thermogravimetry (DTG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) measurements were performed using Shimadzu StandAlone Thermal Analyzer Instruments (TGA-50H and DTA-50) Japan. The analyzer was supplied with a data acquisition and handling system model Shimadzu Chromatopac C-R4AD. Thermal measurements were carried out at 10 C/min heating rate using =15 mg sample weight and in a dynamic atmosphere of Nz (40 ml/ min). Highly sintered a-A1203 was the thermally inert reference material used in the DTA measurements. (Japan), with a Zr-Filtered MoKa radiation source (A= 0.7093 A). The surface area for all samples, calcined at 500-700 C, were determined by the BET method [ 15 ] using N2 as an adsorbate with the aid of a conventional volumetric gas adsorption apparatus [ 16]. Excess surface oxygen measurement for catalysts under investigation was calculated using the iodometric method, in an acidic medium, as reported [ 17 ] elsewhere. Measurements of the activity and selectivity of all catalysts, towards the decomposition of isopropyl alcohol (IP), were conducted in a continuous flow mode under atmospheric pressure. A mixture of 1.4% (IP) in N2, obtained by passing the carrier gas through liquid IP held at 3 C, was used. The total flow rate was kept constant at 115 ml/min. Catalyst sample 0.5 g (in 1 cm I.D. pyrex glass reactor and 16.5 cm long) was stabilized for 2 h at 190 C before measurements. The feed exit gases were analyzed by means of gas chromatograph, Shimadzu GC-14A, equipped with a data processor model Shimadzu Chromatopac C-R4AD (Japan), on a stainless steel column (PEG 20M 20% on Chromosorb W, 60/80 mesh, 3 m X 3 mm) at 110 C. The catalytic activity and selectivity are expressed as [ (mol% of all decomposition products per mol% of supplied IP) x 100] and [ (mol% of particular product per mol% of all decomposition products) X 100], respectively. The basicity of all catalysts was determined by studying the adsorption of acidic molecules using the pulse method [ 18 ] . 0.5 g of each catalyst, calcined at 500 and 700 C, was held in a reactor at the reaction temperature. Pulses of heptane solutions of 0.1 M acetic acid (10 /.cl) were injected into the sample, followed after one minute, by passing the flow of IP. The concentration of unreacted IP was calculated after each injection, and the pulses were stopped when the adsorbate (acetic acid) peak appeared in the chromatogram. The number of pulses was calculated as the basicity of each catalyst. The reaction rates, catalytic activity, selectivity and the kinetic parameters of the dehydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol were determined as explained in detail, previously [ 19 ] . 3. (1) The variation in the strength of the metal-oxygen bond for these three metals, where Mg-O strength (D 9g ) is reported as 393.7 35 kJ/mol [ 23 ] which is close to Ni-O (391.6 3.8 kJ /mol) [ 24 ] . Co-O, on the other hand, is appreciably weaker (368 21 kJ / mol) [ 25 ] than the Mg-O and Ni-O bonds. Therefore, the replacement of 20% (by weight) of Mg-O by Co-O is expected to facilitate the dehydrogenation reaction of IP by more than 20% Ni-O, see Fig. 4 and Table 4. This is in agreement with the concept of cyclic complexes in catalysis, the weaker the metal-oxygen bond the easier is the dehydrogenation reaction of IP [ 26] , where the Co-O bond is weaker than the Ni-O bond. (2) The basicity measurements, for catalysts calcined at 500 C, further support the above mentioned assumption. MgO is a typical basic oxide [ 27 ] , its surface basicity can be altered by the addition of metal ions [ 28 ] . Therefore, when the dehydrogenation of IP was carried out on MgO alone, at the same conditions, it was found to be 99.8% selective towards acetone formation. The conversion of IP over MgO was 99.9% and the rate of formation of acetone (Racer) -41 mmol h-' mca2. MgO has SBET equal to 15 mz/g and its basicity was calculated here as 69.3 X 10- ml/m2 cat. The addition of Co304 to MgO has strongly influenced the basicity of the catalysts [28] calcined at 500 C. Also, the addition of 20 wt% Ni0 to MgO at the same temperature lowered the basicity to nearly one fifth of its original value (i.e., 13.4X 10-3 ml/meat), see Fig. 4. The catalysts of the CoNi/Mg system, in our opinion, have a Bronsted basicity where 0.1 M acetic acid in heptane was used to saturate the basic centres. Two absorption bands at 1578 and 1420 cm-1 were observed in the IR spectra of these catalysts (after the basicity measurements) which are attributed to the COO- groups [ 29 ] . The increased concentrations of Bronsted basicity on the catalyst surface have accelerated the dehydrogenation reaction of IP. Our results for the basicity of the Co-Ni /Mg system are consistent with a previously published work, on a similar system, by Tanabe et al. [30]. Increasing the calcination temperature up to 600 C, of Co-Ni/Mg catalysts, lowered the activity of samples containing higher contents of Co304. This temperature increase does not, however, affect the activity of Ni0/MgO and Co-Ni/Mg (III), as shown from the kinetic data listed in Table 4. Catalysts calcined at 700 C showed the lowest activity compared to those calcined at 500 and 600 C, see Table 4. It is worth mentioning here, that the catalyst containing 20 wt% NiO is the most active one in this series (calcined at 700 C) where % conversion is about 1.7 times greater than the 20 wt.% Co304/MgO at 700 C (see Fig. 5 ). The calculated basicity of NiO (i.e., 11.7 X 10- 3 ml /rrt~at) is about 3.8 times greater than the corresponding basicity of C0304/Mg0. This can be attributed to the decrease in the activity of the loaded Co304 on MgO at higher temperatures [ 31 ] , and consequently a considerable decrease in its activity. (3) The calculated values of excess surface oxygen (Oex) for these catalysts (Table 4) provide some insight for understanding their catalytic activity, especially those calcined at 500 C. At higher temperatures (600 and 700 C) , the amount of Oex could not be correlated with the catalytic activity of such catalysts. The activation energy (dE), the frequency factor (A) as well as the reaction order (n), of the dehydrogenation reaction of EP over Co304/MgO, Ni0/MgO and Co-Ni/Mg(II) calcined at 500 C, are given in Table 5. The dehydrogenation reaction was a first order reaction over NiO/MgO and Co-Ni/Mg(II), while it was zero order on Co304/MgO. Finally, it is concluded that the dehydrogenation of IP over Co-Ni/Mg system, calcined at 500 C for 5 h in air, depends mainly on two factors (i) the metaloxygen bond strength of the catalyst components or the concentration of the exposed cation-anion pair on the catalyst surface, and (ii) the surface basicity of the catalysts where the most active catalyst in this series was Co304/MgO. Increasing the calcination temperature of these catalysts has resulted in a continuous decrease of both the surface area as well as the concentration of the basic sites. The activity of the catalysts calcined at 700 C, was strongly related to the basicity measurements, where NiO/MgO was shown to possess the most active basic catalyst in Co-Ni/ Mg system. Abd El-Hafez Chemistry Department, Faculty of Science, Qena 83511, Egypt * Corresponding author. Catalytic dehydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol was studied over Co3O4NiO/MgO catalysts containing 20 wt% of Co3O4 and NiO, or mixture of both oxides with different molar ratios. Catalysts were prepared from the corresponding nitrates (i.e. Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) and supported on MgO. Catalyst precursors were examined by TG, DTG and DTA, and were calcined between 500–700°C for 5 h in air. The surface area of these samples were calculated using the BET method. Those catalysts calcined at 500°C were characterized by XRD analysis. The amount of excess surface oxygen for these catalysts was calculated iodometrically. Basicity measurements were estimated by the adsorption of acidic molecules using pulse technique method. The vapour-phase dehydrogenation of isopropyl alcohol (IP), has been carried out over the catalysts calcined between 500–700°C. All catalysts showed 99.5% selectivity towards acetone formation. A correlation between the catalytic activity and the basicity of these catalysts has been made. The activation energy and the order of the dehydrogenation reaction of IP over some catalysts are given.
